FORT PAYNE, Ala. - A 14-year-old boy stole a Cessna and went on a late-night joy ride, taking off and landing twice before being arrested, police said.
 
 advertisement
 
 The teen suffered minor cuts and bruises on the second landing because the plane came down hard, causing the landing gear to collapse and the propeller to dig into a road beside the airport, police said.
 
 The teen allegedly took his mother's van from their home Wednesday night and drove to the airport in Fort Payne about five miles away. He said he then found the key in the unlocked plane, removed the Cessna's tie-downs, started the engine, and began driving around.
 
 "The next thing he knew he was in the air," Police Chief David Walker said.
 
 The teen, who police said had never before flown a plane, was in the air for nearly 30 minutes.
 
 Police charged him with theft and took him to a juvenile lockup. The teen was not identified because of his age.
 
 Authorities said the theft raised questions about security.
 
 "We've never had a problem before with planes being stolen, so I guess we have been a little lax in our security," said Larry Noble Cowart, who owns Valley Aviation, which runs the airport and owns the plane.
 
 Cowart said the teen could have entered through the typically unlocked airport gate or climbed a fence.
 
 Fort Payne is a town of 13,000 people located about 80 miles northeast of Birmingham.
 
 -----------------------------------------------------
 Does this prove my point?
Jo Bennett

No, because there is no proven link to computer games. I don't know about the situation in the US, but over here GTA had an 18 certificate, so if kids were playing it then it was the responsibility of their parents to supervise and makes sure they weren't taking the wrong messages from the games. I played GTA and a number of other 15 or 18 rated games before I reached those ages, I don't think it has made me more prone to violence. Those who have difficulty separating a game from reality have bigger problems than computer games to worry about, and their parents really ought to be keeping a closer eye on them.

 Banning the games only makes them more popular. That should be obvious. Let the market decide what should or should not be allowed for sale.

I would say so.

 
 may i generalize this then from violent games to violent tools, such as guns?

may i generalize this then from violent games to violent tools, such as guns?
 
 
 If you generalise like that you would probably need to include any form of media prefixed by violent, for example violent books,violent films,violent plays and violent music.
 
 As someone who is going into the Games industry I get really peeved when people blame Video Games for certain violent acts, for example Doom was partly blamed for the Colombine. Its not the fact that these kids got easy access to fire arms, or that they where bullied by class mates. No its a video Game that caused them to go and kill.
 
 It is an oversimplification to say that Video Games cause violence, you need to look at so many other factors first such as the perpetrators psychological problems.

 Many studies have concluded that access to firearms alone does not lead to an increase in violent crime or homicide.

 If we say yes, will you state your argurment?
zachvac

Indeed. A quick study of history will reveal that there was no youth crime before video games were invented.
 
 emoticon_rolleyes

 
 
 exactly. Do you think that before GTA came out that no kids ever went drag-racing? Do you think there was no violence back in the good ol' days before video games? I don't own any of the above-mentioned games but I have played GTA and Halo at friends' houses and they haven't driven me to want to kill someone. The original question was "why make them?" The answer is that people like to play the games and the sellers want to make money selling the game. I do own a couple other shooting games (none are rated M though) and I don't suddenly want to kill someone. These games are fantasy, they are just a game. Until a direct corelation can be shown between video games and violence (and they have to make sure the corelation isn't just because violent kids like violent video games, that wouldn't prove that the viedeo games were the cause of the violence), they should be sold to anyone who wants to buy them. 
 
 I still say the movie rating system is pretty bad. Why was Star Wars III rated PG-13? I've seen R rated movies that have less violence than some PG-13 movies. And I heard the other day that the rule was for it to be PG-13 and not R you couldn't say the f word more than once and it couldn't be used as a verb. So kids 13-18 can hear the word once, but after that it's bad or something??? I still say keep the ratings system in place to inform parents but allow anyone willing to buy a ticket to buy one for any movie no matter what the rating, and the same with video games (although I think that's how it is in the US with video games).
wilted_laughter

 that individuals are ultimately responsible for the actions they take, regardless of the influences present.
 
 nuremberg principle.

But that's not the same as saying that without the influences they would still have done it. I doubt many Germans would have gone out slaughtering thousands of Jews without living in Nazi Germany and being ordered to do it. They are still responsible for their actions, but that doesn't mean influences, if they can be proven, shouldn't be controlled.
Big_Bear_Scot

The thing i've been wondering about violent games is what happens when games look 100% realistic, which probably isn't too far away.

 
 
 They might look realistic but in most games the Artificial Intelligence Game characters won't act realistic or the physics of the game will not be quite realistic. If you have played Half Life 2 the graphics and physics are excellent but if you look at the sections where you have team mates, the AI is not that great. This spoils the immersion of the game and makes you realise that this is still a game that is effectively an illusion.
 
 If you look at games such as GTA, they have a measure of cartoon violence almost like the violence you would see in the Road Runner, granted the violence in GTA is a bit more realistic, but it is still cartoony(sp?).
 
 I would also like to add that in GTA your actions have consequences, for example if you go on a killing spree the police will chase and try to kill or arrest you. If you get more dangerous more police and even the National Guard come after you. So in essence there are some moral consequences to your actions. 
 
 The only problem I have is that no matter how many killings your carry out and if you are caught by the police you can get out of jail if you have money. I believe the penalty for carrying out these acts in the game is not strong enough, so the player doesn't really care if they get caught or if they get killed. That is really game design issue, if you make the penalties of failure much greater then the player might get turned off your game and not play it.
wilted_laughter
Oh I expect AI and other areas will advance apace as well.

The thing i've been wondering about violent games is what happens when games look 100% realistic, which probably isn't too far away.

Final Fantasy the movie is pretty much where most games are at, and that is obviously a far cry from reality. (not to mention the sheer amount of computing power they needed to make that film).
Killian

They might look realistic but in most games the Artificial Intelligence Game characters won't act realistic or the physics of the game will not be quite realistic. If you have played Half Life 2 the graphics and physics are excellent but if you look at the sections where you have team mates, the AI is not that great. This spoils the immersion of the game and makes you realise that this is still a game that is effectively an illusion.
 
 If you look at games such as GTA, they have a measure of cartoon violence almost like the violence you would see in the Road Runner, granted the violence in GTA is a bit more realistic, but it is still cartoony(sp?).
 
 I would also like to add that in GTA your actions have consequences, for example if you go on a killing spree the police will chase and try to kill or arrest you. If you get more dangerous more police and even the National Guard come after you. So in essence there are some moral consequences to your actions. 
 
 The only problem I have is that no matter how many killings your carry out and if you are caught by the police you can get out of jail if you have money. I believe the penalty for carrying out these acts in the game is not strong enough, so the player doesn't really care if they get caught or if they get killed.  Which is another good point that I believed was already mentioned: Why make them if the user is only going to turn it off after being severely frusterated by being sent to jail for the umpteenth time? Users will tell their friends, "No, don't buy that one. It gets to hard and monotonous."
 
 And on the same note.. wouldn't it be better to, instead of letting the user's character to right away, make the character actually stay in the jail? They would see how boring it is, and thus lowering their will to do any real crimes.
Big_Bear_Scot

Oh I expect AI and other areas will advance apace as well.
 
 
 The next big thing in Computer Games is Hardware Accelerated Physics, this means that you will have a card that sits in your Computer and will do all Physics calculations for your games. 
 This means that some of load will be taken off the CPU, so like what happened with 3D Graphics where the load was taken off the CPU and put onto a GPU, this allowed the programmer to use more of the CPU for things such as AI. Which led to more complex games.
 
 One of the big problems with game AI is that your are effectively faking Intelligence, I will give you an example from one of the projects I worked on at University.
 
 I was working on a car driving game, so we wanted to have cars in the game that acted like traffic. It was up to me to code the AI for those traffic cars, the way I went about the it was to create a system of waypoints around the city where a traffic car would follow. Now this might sound very simple but it was actually relatively complicated. What I first had to do was create a way that the AI could hold the list of waypoints, I decided on a queue structure. This meant that the next waypoint the AI was to go to was at the top of the queue structure, and when the AI reached that waypoint the top element would be removed from the queue and the next one would be the target waypoint.
 Then I had to think of a way to make the AI car steer towards the waypoint, what I had to do was create a vector between the car's current position and the waypoint position which represented the path the car should be on. Then I had to use the cars current direction vector and the path vector to calculate the angle for the car to steer.
 So really that car was not intelligent in any way it only held the next waypoints position, the car position and the car direction. It did not know the position of the player, or any other obstacles on the map.
 
 That is the thing the game programmers will go with the simple thing that gives the illusion of intelligence.
 
 

 And on the same note.. wouldn't it be better to, instead of letting the user's character to right away, make the character actually stay in the jail? They would see how boring it is, and thus lowering their will to do any real crimes.
 
 
 Games are an entertainment product, a game that actually sent the player's character to jail would make a very boring game. If it was a boring game then no one would buy it. So the moral message you would try to impart would not reach anyone.
 
 Anyway games are not there to teach the difference between right and wrong that is what parents are for, a game is just a diversion from reality allowing people to get away from things and escape into a fantasy world where anything goes. 
 
 In game design, you always need to strike a balance between realism and fun. It always depends on what type of game you are going to produce. For example if you are creating a Flight Simulator you would make it as realistic as possible because that is what your target audience wants, but even then you do not have the game totally realistic as that would spoil the fun factor. Imagine if you flew 15 missions are you died when you crashed into a building the Flight Sim allows you to load an old saved game. If it was totally realistic you would have to start a new game.
WhiteFalcon

that individuals are ultimately responsible for the actions they take, regardless of the influences present.
 
 nuremberg principle.

 
 Um yes, its the "users" or individuals that are responsible for the actions they take, and not the "used" or influences. Hence its the users and not used.

They are still responsible for their actions, but that doesn't mean influences, if they can be proven, shouldn't be controlled.

 
 
 There's a difference between being ordered to do something and seeing it happen. If you were in the army and people ordered you to do something it's your duty to do it. If I see it happen on a movie or in a video game, I shouldn't be pushed to do it.
Jo Bennett

There's a difference between being ordered to do something and seeing it happen. If you were in the army and people ordered you to do something it's your duty to do it. If I see it happen on a movie or in a video game, I shouldn't be pushed to do it.

 
 How about I use the example of infantry bayonet training, it uses a very simple simulation (dummies, bags of straw, targets etc) to harden people to sticking a knife into something, so that they won't think twice about it in a combat situation. If you play GTA or something similar, you could be said to be playing a simulation of actual theft murder et al, and hence, when presented with a particular situation, are likely to have fewer qualms about committing the immoral act. However, I'm just playing devil's advocate here, the difference in intent is crucial, infantrymen are AIMING to be able to kill someone with a bayonet, players of video games are not aiming to practise for acting out those event in real life, or if they are they have bigger problems than video games.
Obvious Child
My brother was once playing GTA for several hours and then went for a drive. he saw another car, and thought 'I know, I'll just clip it'. Fortunately he didn't...

Hmm yes I had a similar experience after playing carmaggeddon for a long time. I was a passenger not a driver but I remember wondering why we didn't run over those pedestrians or get a head on bonus on that car coming the oppossite direction.

The criminal element always try to justify their actions. Blame their parents ("I wasn't hugged enough"), blame society ("If you'd just give me a high-paying job for my lack of education I would not have to steal"), or blame some media element ("Violent games/movies/music caused me to do this").
 
 Nope, not buying it. Don't remember too many 16-ton anvils being dropped on people after Looney Tunes was on. 
 
 I've played Halo, and the uber-bouncy DOAx fighting game. Didn't make me want to jack a Humvee and go careening through the downtown.
 
 And these games have ratings on them. For the responsible parents that want to limit mature games being played the solution is simple. Do not allow your kid to play them!! Be a parent, not some lame, aged buddy.

Surely even with completely realistic games - being able to do it in virtual is going to mean someone isn't doing it in real life. But then I don't think that people are going to want to buy a completely realistic game about killing people.
 
 But hey..gives you an extra warning sign as they are bound then to try it on the game rather than real life. Ah, Big Brother makes everything safe.

How about I use the example of infantry bayonet training, it uses a very simple simulation (dummies, bags of straw, targets etc) to harden people to sticking a knife into something, so that they won't think twice about it in a combat situation. If you play GTA or something similar, you could be said to be playing a simulation of actual theft murder et al, and hence, when presented with a particular situation, are likely to have fewer qualms about committing the immoral act. However, I'm just playing devil's advocate here, the difference in intent is crucial, infantrymen are AIMING to be able to kill someone with a bayonet, players of video games are not aiming to practise for acting out those event in real life, or if they are they have bigger problems than video games.

 
 Someone who can't tell the difference between a video game (using thumb to push buttons to control a vehicle on screen) and real life (having hands on a stearing wheel, foot on gas, feeling the change) has more problems than the games themselves. And even in the military, I've heard stories about how the soldiers were almost throwing up as they had to kill other people, and were inches from being killed themselves. Real life is different from video games and the dummy would not be a substitute either. The dummy is more realistic than a video game but still is no substitute for a real live person. I've played racing car games, and games where the object is to run from the cops and stuff. I got my permit 3 months ago and will get my driver's liscence soon. As of now I have yet to feel pressured to go in excess of the speed limit around cars on the median or travel the wrong way on a road to get somewhere faster. This also goes back to the parent, if a parent knows their kid can't tell the difference between a video game and life, they need to do something about it. But I would hope most people would be able to tell a difference between real life and a video game.
KM_Scharnhorst

Gee, let's ban Video games. Than, let's ban violent movies, and violent books, and violent TV shows. Of course, in order to protect our kids from all the mean things in the world, let's just ban porn, swimsuit magazines, and skimpy outfits. Lastly, we'll destroy all weaponry, make peace with everyone, and form a giant peace sign in central Africa!

However, I won't, because I have this thing called "common sense", which I thought everybody had, but I was wrong, dead wrong.

Mom: Hey Timmy, what are you watching on TV?
 
 Timmy: The uncut, unrated version of RoboCop (Buy it today), it's just filled to the brim with violence and gore (which are good for healthy, growing children, but very very bad for pre-deranged children).
 
 Mom: Well that's nice... *Sees the <1 minute scene where Bob Morton is "fooling around" with 2 girls*. OMFGWTFBBQ?! TIMMY, TURN THAT OFF RIGHT NOW, AND GO TO YOUR ROOM!
 
 Timmy: Wha-?! But why?
 
 Mom: You can't watch that sort of empty trash, it'll turn you into a crazy criminal, like those black people! (sorry, but, I'm just trying to mix in some politically incorrect humor, I don't really mean it...maybe...no seriously, I don't mean it.) You want to become a crack addict, get your girlfriend pregnant BEFORE you get married, and get shot in a turf war between two gangs?!
 
 Timmy: What does that have to do with RoboCop? In fact, the core message of RoboCop is that humanity wins through, no matter what happens, and isn't that a lesson I could use to deal with the terrible things that happen in this world?
 
 Mom: QUIET! You will go to your room NOW young man, and you're not allowed to watch this trash ever again! *Throws RoboCop DVD in a fire along with Superman: Issue #1, and an original copy of the Lord of the Rings (because of the presence of wizards)*.
